awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  End-to-End Compilation of Quantum Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is relevant to US national priorities. For example, potential applications of quantum computing include defense-related tasks such as aircraft and flight maneuver identification. Other promising quantum applications are prevalent in logistics problems and can impact American competitiveness in manufacturing. In addition, longer term horizons of quantum computing such as better fertilizer production would dramatically reduce global energy expenditures. The efficiency gains from the proposed end-to-end compilation techniques will address these objectives. The scientific advances funded by this research will enable quantum computing to be applied to a wider range of problems than previously envisioned.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project has the intellectual merit of accelerating the timeline for practical quantum computing. By achieving significant efficiency gains from cross-layer optimization spanning the full quantum stack, practical applications will be executable sooner than otherwise possible. The Phase I research will validate that three proposed quantum techniques outperform the state-of-art found in prevailing quantum research. This work will advance understanding of the ultimate potential and limits of near-term quantum computing. To date, there is still no consensus whether non-error-corrected quantum computers will ever outperform classical computers. To address this overarching research question, the proposed R&D will undertake the technical challenge of end-to-end compilation, which tailors execution of quantum applications to the underlying hardware. This requires eschewing traditional abstraction barriers which are convenient but incur efficiency losses due to indirection. Instead, the proposed work will take as direct a path as possible from the end-user application down to the underlying quantum hardware. Doing so will reveal the fundamental capacity of noisy quantum computers.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Quantum computing is expected to unlock a new era of scientific and technical progress. Of social value, quantum computers will address drug discovery and chemical simulation tasks that are fundamentally intractable for the world’s biggest supercomputers. One such example is the simulation of nitrogenase, an enzyme that could be used to produce fertilizer far more efficiently than currently possible. This would lead to immense improvements in agricultural yield and reductions in greenhouse gases. In the economic arena, quantum computers are expected to enable better solutions to optimization problems in a wide number of industries, enhancing the competitiveness of American manufacturing. Finally, quantum computing is expected to create millions of jobs in new industries involving quantum chemistry and optimization.

However, the current timeline for quantum applications requires waiting 10–20 years until we have enough high-quality qubits to solve practical problems. Our SBIR project studied techniques for realizing practical quantum applications sooner than otherwise possible, with the specific aim of accelerating the timeline for practical quantum computing by 5 years.

Our funded research pertained to three objectives. First, we studied the ability for quantum computers to solve problems on highly-connected networks that pervade in industrial applications. We benchmarked state-of-the-art quantum solvers and observed competitive performance against state-of-the-art classical algorithms. In addition, we devised strategies for improving the performance of these quantum solvers. Second, we developed a novel technique for applying quantum computers to solve continuous-variable problems. In prior work, qubits are best at encoding binary discrete values, but with our technique we show that this restriction can often be surpassed. This enables new applications in domains such as power grid optimization, exemplified by a paper in collaboration with ComEd/Exelon. Finally, we investigated the application of quantum computers to solving constrained optimization problems. We explored a new method called Q-CHOP, which we presented to an audience of physicists at the APS March Meeting.

Common to all objectives, we emphasized the importance of benchmarking—not only between quantum and classical, but also between different types of quantum computers. This led to the publication of SupermarQ, our quantum benchmark platform. The academic paper underlying SupemarQ, which was partially funded by this SBIR grant, received the Best Paper Award at the HPCA conference and has gone one to become a gold standard for technology organizations and policymakers alike. We expect the R&D funded by this SBIR grant to have similar lasting impacts.


Last Modified: 05/15/2022
Modified by: Pranav Gokhale
